number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2016
												This game feels like it is only half finished. From the storyboards used as cutscenes, to the sticky controls (I use an xbox 360 wired controller and the analogue controls are extremely jerky) this game looks as though it could have been a real gem but constantly falls short. There are times when your character literally get's stuck on a ramp or a step, because the programmers haven't made the blocks fit properly. The controls regularly let you down as well, such as the jump (which is the worst jump feature I have ever seen, it's practically a hop) which you can press and time to climb over something and yet you simply don't. The story starts of well, but by the end it is clear that the writyers have no real idea what they are doing and it pretty much goes to hell quickly. The missions have you jumping around the globe in an instant and the storyboard cutscenes do a really poor job of showing you any sort of time passing. The ending of the game just sort of happens as well. It doesn't really explain (at least very well) what your role is in stopping things, you just have to use your powers to overcharge a computer that is connected to Pandora's Box..... Which personally I find pretty funny considering this is based on a Greek myth and so I would have figured that there would have been a more magical and godly way to close the box, but apparently not. Finally, the main reason I am leaving a negative review....I could have lived with everything I have said up until this point and whilst I wouldn't have recommended the game, I wouldn't have complained either. However, right at the end of the game there is an elevator that is simply broken. You stand in the Elevator to go to the final platform, and your character falls straight through and into nothing, seeing the worldspace dissappear into black above you. I looked this up and it is a known issue that has been complained about since what I am assuming is release (2012). There are posts that claim there are ways to fix it, but none of these fixes worked for me. Frankly though, I shouldn't have to fix a game that has been out for at least 4 years anyway. This is a gamebreaking bug and the developer has quite literally ignored it and ignored the complaints that it has triggered. This is unacceptable and frankly it is disgusting. The only way I could complete the game was by using a noclipping (walk through walls) hack that someone on the forums suggested. This led me to wander through the world space until I found the next trigger point to be able to continue the mission. Again, this is pathetic and unacceptable. Do not buy this game. Whether it is £10 or 1p, I would not recommend paying for a game that is riddled with bugs and where the developer clearly doesn't care. Save your money and buy something from a studio that cares about the product that they release.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2015
												A decent cinematic FPS compareable to Half-Life, Bioshock or Metro from its gameplay, pacing and progression making you traverse post-apocalyptic-ish levels by rather indirect means and engaging various types of enemies inbetween.A wealthy/evil entrepreneur leading a secret society tricked you, a silent mercenary, into opening Pandora's Box in modern New York. Mythological creatures assault the world and you traverse broken - most of the time urban - areas in an effort to halt/reverse the spread utilizing the help of another secret society, man-made firepower and a signet that was burned into the back of your hand when you opened the box and that allows you to absorb energy - "Animus Vitae" - from dead creatures restoring your health as well as stagger them briefly with a burst of it.The story is rather basic stuff of evil guy dooming the world and you going to save the day. Well, more or less, as the ending isn't as definitive - the devs clearly left room for a sequel which I would like to see as there is sort of a cliffhanger making me a little hungry for more, but I'm not sure if this will ever happen for this seems like an under-the-radar title. The gamebreaking bug towards the end that the devs obviously never got around to fix seems to be a proof of that (there is one workaround or another for this bug, but its still a severe one).Aiming is rather hard for reasons unknown to me. I haven't fiddled around with the options much but I've read other reviewers had similar issues. It's rather imprecise and twitchy. Putting the crosshair on a certain small spot is almost impossible. It's similar to what I experienced in Bioshock. It's doable when shooting from the hip but aiming down the sights or going for specific hit zones (like the heads) can be a pain. Some reviewers argued this adds to the challenge, and while this is true at first glance it's very artifical nonetheless (I could also blindfold one of my eyes or tie one of my hands to my back to increase the challenge).Sometimes I would have hoped for more checkpoints. One boss fight or another and some puzzle-ish scenes with me interacting with various environmental things to open blocked paths while certain enemies "stalking" me took me longer than I had expected. It felt a little tedious at times. When I took more care and understood how things worked I got them done though.The characters could have deserved a bit more love. Besides you, the silent mercenary, and the evil businessman there is a somewhat self-confident and sexy-ish female companion (who may remind the player of Alyx Vance - but then she too was an archetype character), some high-ranking military guy advising/ordering you around and nameless field-operatives you wouldn't want to get to know better as they like to get eaten by the creatures. The characters are not bad for what they are supposed to be - they serve their roles and their voice actors are good - but they aren't surprising or too memorable either. Still, despite it's flaws and that one bug it's game that plays out fairly well and consistent from start to end. It holds a decent premise of throwing mythological creatures at the world and the player, providing some nice settings (New York Times Square for example) and being pretty good at creating the ambiance that the world is getting torn apart by those creatures, as there are always griffons, werewolves and other creatures lurking about and stalking the close or distant skies, the roofs and walls, the waters and just about anything else. The fight between the two secret societies with you in the middle of it felt quite believable too. The game takes some effort into teaching mythology by providing brief intel about the creatures you encounter (and how the two societies are related to the whole affair) and putting you into the need to adapt a little when fighting them because their nature gives them certain strengths and weaknesses. There are pickable data logs scattered around the levels too that flesh out their background a little, either informing you about the activities of hostile or allied agents on the field or about former citizens and how they experienced the attacks from the creatures. Had this game gotten more polish and maybe more advertising perhaps it could have been brought to a similar level as Half-Life, Bioshock, Metro or other games of this kind. It's not too far away from that either, however, and in this manner I believe this is an underrated game.

												The developers didn't put any effort into making this game, so why should I put any effort into my review of their game.This whole game is mediocre, Everything is average. It tries to do horror at several points in the game, but fail at even that. It's a boring game with minimal effort put into itThere's a gamebreaking glitch at the end of the game, you have to take an elevator but if you don't limit the FPS to 30 in the config, you'll fall throught the elevator into a void and die. Amazing.To fix this glitch, go to:  "C:\Users\<User Name>\Documents\My Games\Legendary\PandoraGame\Config"Open "PandoraEngine.ini" with notepadFind "MaxSmoothedFrameRate=300" and change it to "MaxSmoothedFrameRate=30"Once you hit a new checkpoint you can exit the game, change it back to 300 and play again

												I've tried to like Legendary several different times on different systems and end up turning it off at the same spot. My biggest issue with this game is the fact that enemies keep spawning in the same location untill that spot is destroyed by dumping water on it. Every time I think I cleared an area of enemies, I would then start to work my way to the next area only to be attacked from behind by another. I've only play the game for about 30 minutes and this review is based only on that bit of time. It may be a great game for those who can forgive the respawning enemies issue My score for this game: 4/10

content:
27, 2014
												Traditional Rating - 5.5/10Recommendation - Play Singularity instead.This game kind of slides into the same slot as Singularity: Slightly-older, somewhat-obscure, non-AAA shooter. Unfortunately, where Singularity shines, this game falls flat. Where Singularity's story is interesting, this one is bland. Where Singularity's gunplay and enemies are interesting, Legendary's are frustrating. The only exception is the BEASTLY fire-axe, which I rather enjoyed.-The graphics in this game are passable. They fit their purpose, but show their age.-The sounds are actually quite good. The burst-fire rifle in particular I enjoyed.-The voice acting is on the low side of B-movie quality. C+ movie, maybe.-The enemies, for the most part, are quite frustrating. The one enemy I did enjoy is the little rolling brimstone demons. Their AI was fun.Overall, the game is a disappointment. On the high-side, it's generic. On the low-side, it's teeth-gratingly frustrating. For example, let me explain the moment where I gave up on the game:There is a gigantic golem thrashing around the city streets (who for some reason attacks everyone else, but never tries to attack me), and I'm running around charging up EMP generators. Working on the 3rd one, I ran into a building filled with little pixie enemies that can only be hit when they feel like it (they turn "ethereal" and seem to only turn solid when your back is turned), and some little will-o-wisp thing immediately possesses the EMP generator and moves it up a floor. After getting slashed in the back by a dozen more of the stupid little pixies, I make it upstairs, slightly charge the EMP, and it moves up another floor. Kill another dozen pixies, run up another floor, charge up some more, EMP moves to bottom floor again. Run all the way down after killing 2 dozen more pixies, charge up some more, EMP moves to middle floor again. Kill more pixies, run up another floor, charge up more, EMP moves AGAIN. Run to top floor, all the while killing pixies, charge up some more, it moves to a new spot on top floor, charge it up some more, and IT MOVES AGAIN! Smash Alt+F4 so hard the USB drive on my desk falls over.That is literally an exact account of what happens in that section. Not one single part of that whole encounter were challenging. The entire thing was just pecking at me. The dumb little pixies posed no threat, except to my patience, and there was no environmental danger either. If there were some increasing level of danger every time it moved, that's one thing, but to move the EMP generator just for the sake of moving it is nothing but busywork.I get that that is just one tiny moment in the game, and the rest of it could be good, but every single part of the game I did see was utterly joyless, and given how badly that one section ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off, I'm done giving Legendary any chances. I did not enjoy it.

content:
er 25, 2013
												While at times the concept is taken to a neat place it also suffers from unimaginative set pieces that drag down much of the style. Sometimes the game can host fun firefights while most of the time the level design is linear in a claustrophobic and tedious way. It also suffers from awkward sub-mechanics as well, especially regarding its enemy types.  For instance you have werewolves that you can permanently kill through unusual means, only to face them in situations where they infinitely respawn which ultimately negates the point of killing them off permanently.  Awkward design decisions are plentiful throughout the experience.  Also why would they design jumping puzzles when the player can only jump upwards or two to three feet max?But thats not to say that the game is entirely without fun, there are a couple of neat firefights here and there.  For the most part though it is an jaunt through tedious levels with design that will bore and frustrate the player.  So while there is fun to be had ultimately the majority of the experience is not worth playing.

content:
0, 2013
												Legendary is one of those FPSes that had an interesting premise: i.e. fight legendary creatures (griffons and more), but ultimately came away as a Half-life clone, where you go through the world exactly as the developers intended, watch somethings happen in the gameworld (many instances of tentacles of creatures dragging off / killing NPCs) and you can't interfere. While it was fresh and we saw scientist got pulled through ceiling hole and then gibblets came back out. it's no longer so interesting a decade later. Furthermore, the game basically postulated that not only the legends were all real (all the myth like werewolf, tentacles, and much more were real, there are also hidden forces, very well equipped (equipvalent to modern military), that just suddenly get into the city instead of the real military. Ancient secret societies that stayed together forever, and evil mastermind and all that. It's a lot like Underworld, except it wasn't a war between Vampires and Lycans, but merely, Black Hand (evil) and Council of 98 (good), humans vs. humans. Mechanically the game is a normal FPS, albeit with a bit of extra thing about this "animus". If you defeat one of these special critters, you get to collect their life force, the animus. It can be used to heal yourself, or to power actual devices (why? Don't they have batteries or generators?)  And I'm only a little in. And there are certainly a lot of these creatures.  You can also use the energy to do a "stun bolt". As some of the enemies are infinite respawns, you shold not run out of energyThe game is also dotted with "environmental puzzles", most of which are rather simple, and one of the earliest stumpers simply didn't give enough hint. At other times, the "break the 4th wall" hint totally broke the mood. For example, how do you kill a werewolf? You "kill" it, then cut off its headAll in all, Legendary is a relic of the FPS era, with an interesting premise, but so far, there was little of any fight against the critters

content:
, 2014
												Basically the best worst game I have ever played. While I doubt it was done intentionally, Legendary acheives a level of such rediculousness through its story, bad acting, and general concept that it is an absolute masterpiece and a joy to play. It blends science fiction with the legend of Pandoras box, throws in some random mythological creatures (such as werewolves, griffins, minators..,) and it some how "works." The game feels reminiscent of older games like Doom and the outdated graphics work to it's advantage in that light. The controls aren't perfect, and occasionally feel a little "clunky" (iron sights less accurate than shooting from the hip,) but you quickly adapt by the time you're through the first level.  I picked this up for less than a dollar and I suggest you do too. It's worth a good laugh and to kill some time. Don't go into it expecting the greatest gaming experience of your life though, go in with the same expectations you would watching a b-movie horror/scifi flick, and you'll have a blast reveling in the sheer absurdity of it all.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												In a gaming industry with increasing repetition, it's nice to see a game take a chance with something different, and I think it pays off in Legendary. The mix of enemies is nice, as well as the feeling of being caught in a three-sided conflict. Each of the monster enemies has different strategies, creating some tactical variety. The environments, though not particularly original, suit the gameplay quite nicely (although frequently feeling cramped, there aren't enough big open areas that make for the best fights in the game). Unfortunately, Legendary does feel somewhat lacking in content; there are few weapons, and there's little reason to use anything other than the newest weapons you've found (and only one melee weapon available). While the enemies are varied, there's only a few types; more monsters to fight and more variety amongst enemy soldiers would be welcome. The game is also fairly short, and can be beaten in an afternoon without much trouble (which suits the limited enemy types). Animus powers (the games spells, for lack of a better term) also seem underutilized. Walking away from Legendary, it almost feels like a teaser for a better game that, sadly, won't be coming. Overall, I recommend Legendary for an afternoon of fun; it's enjoyable and different, but it won't blow anyone away.

content:
9, 2014
												Ah *sniff* , do you smell that? Its the smell off poor game design. If this game was a potato(its strikingly similar to one), it would be the first potato of the Irish Potato Famine(wiki link here: "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" ) that killed of a million Irish citizens between 1845 and 1852. A friend gifted this game to me when it was on sale for $0.74, instead of the normal $4.99 price tag. Even $0.74 is overpriced for this potato-esque game, a potato costs about $.33, instead of buying this game, you could buy 2 potatoes for $0.66, that's 8 cents less than the price of the game! That is like getting two good potatoes for the price of a different diseased potato(the different potato being "Legendary" of course). When the game isn't on sale, buying Legendary for it's $4.99 price tag is an even bigger mistake than buying it while its on sale for $0.74. Don't waste your money, buy something that is actually useful and buy a 5 pound bag of Russet potatoes for about $3.99, and a bag contains 11-13 potatoes. So not only is it a dollar cheaper, but a bag of potatoes contains 11-13x  the content of "Legendary". Its simple math really, 1 bag of potatoes = 11-13 potatoes, "Legendary" = 1 (diseased) potato , so , 1 times 11 = 11,or, 1 times 13 = 13, and thats how a bag of potatoes has 11-13x the content of "Legendary". Don't waste your money, and buy potatoes instead #Potatoes2014 #PotatoSimulator2014  One last note, the title of "Legendary" is very misleading as the game is definitely not legendary, "Potato Famine" or "Autism in a Bottle" are more suitable namesPlease, for the sake of potatoes, DON'T buy this gameI'm serious, paying someone $4.99 to kick you in the crotch is a smarter way to spend your moneyHell, burning a $5 dollar bill holds more value, you atleast get a miniscule amount of entertainment unlike playing "Autism in a Bottle"This concludes my review of "Legendary", I hope you had fun

content:
, 2014
												Steam needs a neutral setting, or a slider or something, because Legendary is a strange one. I got it on the cheap long ago, and it's an interesting concept, if nothing else.The game revolves around you, Deckard, who causes the world to be devastated with monsters of forgotten mythology. At the same time, you have parties for and against you, trying to stop you because apparently, they like these monsters to destroy the world, and to help you because the perils of survival rest in your hands. Convenient because you hold the power of Pandora's Box, able to kill or heal with the arcane energy that you recharge by killing your foes and absorbing said energy.I use these fancy words, but the game is just an FPS for the fairness of it. It runs in Unreal Engine 3, making it semi-pretty, but very meh in visuals. The level design isn't exactly impressive, the world around you is crumbled worse than a Call of Duty setpiece. It's all so standard, the only thing driving it is the mythical creatures that attack and your abilities.The game info states that it's a singleplayer game, but it DOES have online multiplayer and support for a 360 controller, although you would be hard-pressed not to use the KB and mouse, since this is a PC title. Obviously, the game's age and lackluster quality means there's basically no community for this game, though.At the time of review, this game is on sale for 3 quarters. Less than a dollar, a couple of trading cards will get you this game.$0.74. For the price, I'd say you'll get more than your money's worth out of it. For the $5 price it would usually hold, I would not recommend it.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
y 3, 2015
												An FPS released in 2008 and seems dated even for then.You're a thief hired to open Pandora's Box. Apparently, you've never heard of it before...Anyway, as expected all hell breaks loose. Mythical monsters roam the planet destroying mankind. (Weak werewolves, regular were wolves, griffons, golems, fire things, mintoaurs, and some bug things.) Now you have to find a way to reseal the box.Game play is very meh. There are oddly long stretches between fights throughout the game. Your weapon choices are very limited and as pointed out earlier, there isn't a large variety in enemies. Also, I've gone through every possible thing you can do in the game yet Steam shows me as having only played 12 hours.The bad part of that is it includes all the time I had it paused and at least an hour of troubleshooting.Why was I troubleshooting? Because there is a game killing bug right at the end of the game that the developer never cared about fixing. Getting around it requires some forum searches, some file editing, and possibly installing FRAPS (that fixed it for me).So yeah, there's a bug at the end that many people hit, and was never fixed, that literally stopped your progress cold. For me, that's unforgivable, even if the rest of the game wasn't blah.I'd say my feelings aren't unique because they set this game up for a sequel and you'll notice there isn't one.Skip it.

It works as a game, but is incredibly boring and mediocre.And I swear that this game only has two tracks of music.

content:
2015
												There's a clear issue with stupidly hard parts on normal. I genuinely recommend play it on easy. The bigger creatures are very hard to beat on normal difficutly, and you end up swearing at it. It constantly goes from easier bit to incredibly hard bit. Shooting is inconsistent, meaning sometimes enemies go straight down, and others take all eight rounds of the shotgun. It has a lot of, 'where do I go now' and 'how do I do this', moments.Weapons only feel medoicre-average maybe, and they swap positions in your mouse scroll. That means you struggle to find the weapon you want in time. Literally sometimes the axe is bound to key 1, then key 3. Your other two weapons keep changing slot. There's another really nasty insult which is the radio voice chatter. It is infuriatingly squelchy and screechy. In headphones it's pure pain. I do not know how anyone had the audacity to create and put that in a game.Overall it's an average-poor old type shooter. Shame because the idea is average-good. I decided to buy it because I saw werewolves and guns on the Steam store page screenshots. In the sale I bought it for £0.39, so I lost nothing because I easily go the fun back. I have played five hours and am tired of it. I might finish it though, but can't say right now; 50/50. I can't recommend it, and I can understand its poor reviews. However if you play on easy and give a it a once through, I can see genuine fun in it.

content:
r 3, 2016
												Spark Unlimited, the developers of Legendary, were always /at best/ a B-list developer and their previous effort - "Turning Point: Fall of Liberty" - was so terrible that when I first played "Legendary: The Box", it definitely colored my opinion of this game. But six years later, I can replay this game and appreciate it for its... no, wait, it is still a terrible game. It's just not as terrible as I remember.There are occasional moments of - well, not of brilliance, but perhaps of adequacy - that make the game bearable, but these are overshadowed by the terrible story, characters, level design, gun-play and monsters. The game is extremely repetitive with very little variety in textures, monsters or guns. Even when the developers did throw in something interesting - such as the massive golem in the early levels - it rarely serves as much more than a backdrop to the overused werewolves and salamanders that make up the bulk of your opponents. In other words, I didn't actually get to fight the golem because that might be /fun/. On the other hand, it made me realize that a lot of the other "terrible" games I've played over the past few years aren't so bad in comparison.

												I don't understand why this game has so much negative criticism. I decided to play this seeing that it was only around £1.80, I liked the Idea of the game. The gameplay is relatively straight-forward: Do this, kill this, find your way around or out of this, etc. However, the game's plot is what makes it so good. --SPOILER ALERT!--The story places you in the boots of a man who is persuaded into opening Pandora's box, he inadvertedly sets the world into a cataclysm as mythological creatures begin to invade the world, the myths and the humans are caught in a war. However it only appears that the myths aren't the major threat. early on you find out about the man who hired you -LeFay- is attempting to control the creatures for himself and you are brought into a group known as the Council of 98 who are attempting to stop LeFay's army's -The Black Order- plans. Both the council of 98 and the black order are caught in a war against each other and the myths.-My opinion-This game is very good, and I believe that the game is worth playing, as it is extremely well developed and the gameplay is well executed.

content:
ry 27
												TL;DR: Uninteresting console game from 2008, that has nothing for itself. Way overpriced (even at 3 bucks). Not worth your time (even if you're in sentenced for life in prison).----This game is from 2008, and it hasn't aged well. However, there are reasons why it didn't age well, as it wasn't particularily good to begin with. If you watch the trailer, you will hear: "With Legendary, we're gonna take it where we've never gone before...", "It's unique, it hasn't been done yet.", "You really need to understand the magnitude of destruction that they're causing", or "All the rules are completely different". As far as I can understand, that has to do with the size of the destructible environment that supposedly has been created for the game.So let's start with that, the destructible environment. The first game I can remember that featured really destructible environment was Red Faction. Red Faction was released in 2001, if they're talking about that, they're wrong. Destructible has been done yet. And, to be fair, Legendary does not feature destructible environments: the first weapon you get is a fireman axe (and what better destruction tool than a fireman axe? It's designed for it!), and it doesn't even work on simple wooden boxes at the beginning (and the axe leaves a mark on any surface that looks more like an ink track than anything else) while it works on wooden boxes further on. At this point, it's not even wrong anymore, it's "alternative facts".So let's give them the benefit of the doubt (since the trailer is as unclear as it can be) and assume that they're talking about the size of the ennemies you have to fight. Really big ennemies surely haven't been done in video games prior to this one, right? I'm not even going to mention Kraid from Super Metroid since it's a 2D game, but the "Necrogiant" from painkiller (2004) is pretty big. And that's just one example. So not that either.Let's give it another try, what the game innovates with are the Mythical creatures you have to hunt down in first person. It must be that, right? Well, just to name one, Daikatana (from 2000).So then, what is new with this game? Nothing. This is one of the blandest game I have ever played.The worst aspect probably is the level design; but the game design also is terrible. For starters, you can heal from every single infinitely-respawning enemy (of which I've seen only six sorts - bosses and enviroment hazard excluded) you defeat, therefore completely obliterating any feeling of challenge or difficulty, as I found myself running with the axe to any ennemy, head first, most of the time (which caused me to die on the first griffin enconuter, btw).Then, the environments all look the same, the "environmental puzzles" (very probably a buzzword at the time) are all but interesting, and feel forced on the player. Same goes for the occasional QTE that seldom happens when an Alpha werewolf attacks you: they aren't mapped to any button in the vicinity of those you're using (they're mapped to the arrows - while the game uses WASD and the mouse). Another sign of a console feature rushed in the game at the last moment.To continue on the level design, the game is an utterly linear set of rooms and corridors, chained one after another (the character can hack any code locked door on his way by maintaining two wires in contact for a long enough time - essentially becoming a door knob that takes ages to operate. And there often are multiple ones in a row), with checkpoints that sometimes trigger without anything happening between them (aside the character walking). You very soon find yourself routinely playing, and forgetting what you are doing.To make matters worse, as I mentionned above, the game design is also to blame: the enemy cover system is binary they either are behind cover (it does not matter if you can shoot them), or not; and the aim-assist is always on, as if the game was to be played only on consoles. And as a canonical console game, the weapon selection is horrendous (you don't even have a selection wheel, it's button based, but designed to be mapped on only four slots, two of which are taken by the axe and the nades/molotovs), limited and takes ages (you can easily get killed by a tentacle if you were in the process of swapping your weapon).Graphically, the game is horribly looking, and I have a GTX 780, with all settings maximized. If you find the screenshots on the store page to be good looking, I invite you to see them in full size: I too was finding them more than acceptable in low resolution. There are no options whatsoever, let alone the possibility to change the FOV. Ingame, the models are pretty dated, the textures are very low definition, and the animations are notably unnatural.The audio of the game is pretty unremarkable, which totally fits with the rest of that title.The plot is as uncomplicated and dumbed down as it gets. Here is an except of a conversation (or monologue rather) that represents pretty well the level of thought put into this game: "This isn't what <name redacted> said was going to happen today. I had no idea those creatures were going to be released, or that he'd try to kill both of us". And the worst part is, they even paid the voice over actors for dubbing that...Now let's talk about the bugs. This game doesn't have so many of them, as it's mostly plagued by mediocrity, but a steaming pile of crap like this wouldn't be complete without its utterly game-breaking bug at the most appropriate place: right before the final boss: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=795351To summarize the bug (or in case the link dies), what happens is that as soon as you step through the elevator (one of many, many, MANY elevators) that leads you to the last level, you fall through the floor of that elevator, take damage, and can't continue the game. You can reload the last checkpoint, only to have the same problem. Again and again. The fix seems to be to change the MaxSmoothedFrameRate parameter from 300 to 60 or even 30. What fixed it in my case was to set the parameter to 10. I let you imagine how the game runs at 10 FPS, or how easy it is to play in those conditions.My only wish is that I had got this review, and a speedrun video of the game; instead of Legendary. That would have saved me some precious time.

content:
8, 2014
												Legendary is a legendary pile of garbage.   First off, let me say that the video on the store page trying to depict this game as some sort of carfullky nurtured game with developers that are passionate about how "epic" this game looks is a complete lie. This game is a march past setpiece after setpiece not unlike COD in its complete lack of choice in game design. The game has you walking down linear hallways around 90% of the game, which can be fine for a game, but when I am in a large open area and the places that I can walk are defined by wrecked cars, it is obvious the game developers are fairly bad level designers.   The combat design is just about as abysmal as the level design, being monotonous and boring solely because of the lack of content in this area. There are really ony a few enemies for the first 3 hours of the game, some being monsters and some being human. There is also a complete lack of imagination in the weapon choice, leaving battles to never feel unique or even necessary. The monster enemies drop energy that you can absorb in order to execute powers like healing and pushing enemies back just like in Bioshock, which seems like a neat mechanic, but it basically boils down to an extra health bar or in a situation were you need to "Charge something up" the way to advance the mission. One of the biggest issues is that the human enemies do somewhat unavoidable hitscan damage that can drain your healthbar quickly, but then they do not yield any energy to restore your health when they die. This forces these parts of the game to be a grind of memorizing where all the enemies are hiding behind cover and making sure you are not shot.  I could forgive most of these complaint and just leave it under "The budget was too small" or some other likely excuse, but the game has a nasty habit of just plain wasting your time. I like to call these AGOs, or Artificial Game Lengtheners. It's things that are put in to games like Legendary in order to make up for the lack of actual gameplay time and pad out the game length. Some of the feature AGOs in Legendary include: doors that take 10 seconds to open popping up very often in a level, breaking platform making you fall to a lower place to do a section of platforming again, and long enemy gauntlets while you are waiting for one of you allies to "fix" the device of the moment a la Half-Life 2. Overall, it gives the game an air of unfinishedness, knowing these things were probably added to make the pitifully short game just a bit longer.   Overall, this game is just an unispired mess. It riffs of so many other games that you wonder if the developers had an original thought in mind for the whole game. It tries to be Bioshock, Half-Life 2, Crysis 2, and Fear all at once and doesn't understand that many of the gameplay elements in each of these games were used to accomplish a certain purpose: a purpose that is lacking in Legendary. Don't buy this game unless you want to study what NOT to do in a shooter, because this isn't fun in any sense of the word.

content:
2014
												Overall a good concept with some decent ideas that obviously were intended to be much larger than what it was. However its the final presentation, very clunky controls and game breaking bugs that let this game down.The first three quarters of the game are enjoyable, but as the diificulty ramps up in later stages the clunky and sluggish controls make it difficult to survive encounters even on normal. The key problem is that you can't jump higher than 1 foot, which means you'll constantly hump scenery and find that a single brick becomes an invisble wall, not the best thing to happen when retreating from a werewolf. Also the sprinting action which is essential later in the game doesn't always work. A lack of hit detection on the monsters also makes it difficult to know if your actually doing them any damage, most of which are bulletsponges. A standard FPS romp through New York sewers then London sewers then back to more New York sewers are telltale signs of a lack of creativity.  Finally this is the first time since the ElderScrolls 3 where I found myself constanly clipping out of the world, in particular right before you battle the final boss. So gamebreaking endgame glitch, sluggish controls and lack of imagination ruin an otherwise decent experience, pick this game up below £5/$5 and its a decent way to waste a weekend but don't expect anything brilliant.

content:
19, 2014
												I know this game is from 2008, so it's going to seem like I'm picking on it a little bit.Aesthetically, it's a game with big, although not pretty skyboxes. The game is so unashamed to use invisible walls that it becomes massively obvious where the level designer wanted you to go. Gameplay wise, it's your standard First person shooter, with lots of knee high walls, your default squishy human, hard wearing mythical creatures and tank-like minotaurs, but most enemies except for the minotaurs could be taken down in a few well placed shots. The story concept had mileage to go, but somehow this game really didn't do it justice, either they've had to cut the campaign and story down for financial reasons, or from publisher deadlines, but if I'm honest, I don't care. The ending left me feeling like it'd just cut the wettest of farts and left. It has so many bad story cliches, that if it had any more, I'd have thought I were in a printing mill.As for the voice acting, I don't know whether they used someone's fake english accent, or they just found some seriously stuck-up lady, but the accent sounded so unbelievably indignant throughout the game, even when you had to save her, not to mention the drawn-out exposition. Hey, I get it lady, I need to go to these three doohickeys and blow them up to shut down the watchamacakllit before time rund out and it goes off... What's that lady, oh, you want to explain it for the extra special soldiers in the room? Sure, it's not like the world is ending and we're on the clock.It still has potential for a sequel or DLC levels if they had left out that deus ex machina ending, but sadly, what has been done can not be undone.

												i honestly wish more people bought this game because its a very interesting concept and id like to see more like it in gaming these days. while overall the game can be very frustration when you have such little health and fighting werewolves and hidiously out of place enemy troops you can die very quickly and very easily. the visuals are pretty beautiful for the scale they have, everything looks crystal clear and increadibly detailed. overall its a good game that suffered from getting far to much money put into it for a relitively neice title.  im pretty sure the game failed to live up to the studios high expectations but even regardless of that its still a very interesting expiriance that i dont regret owning or playing.

												This game is not as bad as everyone claims it to be, the story is quite good and some areas have some really memorable parts, if you love Mythic or Legendary Creatures this is a must to get, you get to kill Werewolves, Fairies, Minotaurs and other creatures.It has just one horrible horrible unforgivable mistake, there is this glitch when getting to the ending of the game where you get into an Elevator and you keep falling CONSTANTLY through the Elevator floor into your death, there is no way to avoid this unless you get into the game ini settings and set the game to 30 FPS max, anything higher and you will keep falling through the floor, another horrible mistake is the unskipable cinematics.Overall is not as bad as everyone claim, seriously the game is good but is rather short.My score for this game is 7.2 out of 10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2016
												I've tried, honestly. Several times. Several times i have tried really hard to enjoy this game. I can't, i just can't. Bought this because of the description and some positive reviews that said that this game is like Half Life, Doom, F.E.A.R., etc, that it's a horror, it's immersive, it's fun, it's a good action, you name it. Well, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I was really just looking for a simple shooter, that's all. I knew the game was cheap but hey, there are many examples out there when cheap games turned out to be a real good fun after all. This one, nope. You remember that grip that Quake or Doom or Unreal or Gunman had on you when you first started playing them? Incredibly catchy from the very start, that grip just didn't let go even when it was almost morning and you had to go to school or work in a few hours but just couldn't stop playing. And don't tell me you weren't in a hurry after school/work to get to the computer again and continue playing ;) Yeah, i've been there too, wonderful feeling, lots of positive energy. These games were so simple yet genius. They had very comfortable pretty much everything. Controls, configuration menus, gameplay, concept... Again, you name it, all i'm saying that these games were so much of a success also because they were SIMPLE. Speaking about Legendary, i feel like it tries too hard to be that simple. And well, it succeeds. A bit. Monsters taking all over the place? Check. Protagonist that possessess some supernatural powers and doesn't talk unless absolutely necessary? Check. Dark filled with water tunnels? Check. Creepy sounds? Check. Gory scenes? Check. Weapons? Check. Bad guys? Check! See, everything's in place. The concept is somewhat simple yet catchy. Instead of some demons or dinosaurs or mutants we have mythological creatures gone wild. Not bad, not bad at all! With all this, i have no problem at all. The way the game is made TECHNICALLY is a problem. - First of all, controls, they are clumsy. It's simply not comfortable to operate your character. Movements feel just... i don't know, weird. All the time playing i had a feeling that there was a slightest delay between pressing a button and protagonist responding to it. Like, maybe less than half a second or something, but you can really tell, and that's what makes gameplay uncomfortable from the very beginning. The same goes with shooting btw. Ironsights are useless.- No flashlight. Considering the game is mostly dark, the flashlight would come in handy, but there's none, too bad. It's a small thing, yes. But as the great Sherlock Holmes used to say, "There's nothing more important than small things". - Endless enemies. Now that's more serious of a problem. I've only been like, maybe a few hours into the game so far and i've already encountered what, 5 points where the enemies just kept on coming. Now, i'm not saying that it's critical, pretty much every shooter has such moments. But not every 20 minutes, for all sakes!!! I love to explore places in shooters, i love to walk around, searching for ammo, medpacks, some hidden things, just admiring level design in general. Here, you ain't got no time to explore. It's just endless shooting and running with no time for a break to look around. Dislike.- Soul collecting/healing mechanics. The protagonist has a power to collect "souls" from fallen enemies and use this energy to restore his health, there are no medpacks. Interesting concept, hands down, encourages you not to avoid fighting monsters. The problem is endless enemies. Sucking the magical power down takes some time. With monsters constantly reappearing, you won't have much time to devour enough souls and heal yourself which also takes time, because you are going to be too busy shooting and reloading. This often leads to the death of protagonist because you just can't shoot, reload, throw grenades, consume souls, heal yourself and charge up the generator AT THE SAME DAMN TIME!!! IT. IS. NEARLY. ♥♥♥♥ING. IMPOSSIBLE. Well, of course, one can always switch difficulty to EASY. But i don't know how about you, my friend, but if i play a shooter, i play it on HARD or HARDEST. I love a challenge in FPS, but in this case, i gotta admit, i switched to EASY more than i wanted. Until i just gave up. Not good.- Checkpoint reloading time. Is enormous. Reloading the last saved checkpoint takes a very, very long time. I don't know why though, because visuals in this game are less than average. In fact this game looks like it was made 10-15 years ago. Why does it load so long, i have no idea. As i mentioned before, technically the game is... not so good. And it doesn't run smooth also, i think because it's probably a port. So yeah, here you have it. This game could have been fun, it could have been relaxing, it could have been enjoyable. Just a simple good old shooter that is so hard to find these days, a massage for your spinal cord. But unfortunately, all the good aspects have been killed by poor optimization mostly. No toggle crouch option, no flashlight, endless monsters... It could all be forgivable. If not for poorly made mechanics. To be honest i feel a bit guilty giving Legendary a thumb down, i wish there was an option to give games on Steam neutral reviews. The game definitelly has a potential, it could of made a good average shooter. Given into the right hands, it could have been a tasty candy in a shiny wrapper! Too bad that the developers didn't give their creation enough attention that it certainly deserved. Seriously, it feels to me like developers were just lazy! They didn't polish. I don't want to look for half a minute at a loading screen after each death. Dammit, the game just plays clumsy in general! Shame. The recipe was good, a little more seasoning was needed. A little more salt and sugar and a bay leaf. Here in russia you can buy meat for less than 10 dollars and make some very tasty Aspic out of it. All it takes is some effort. If only a few things were fixed, this review would be changed immediatelly, sigh. Sorry Legendary, not recommended. Just can't. Even considering the price. Too bad.

content:
21, 2015
												Legendary is a decent budget FPS, but I cannot in good conscience recommend it with a game breaking bug in the last level that requires noclip mode to get past. I also had to glitch through one of the bosses by hiding in a corner behind some rubble, because it was seemingly impossible to dodge its attacks while it absorbed entire clips from a machine gun without flinching. It is a shame because the game has a lot of unrealized potential and some stunning visuals at times, despite an overall cheap feel. The very first level sees an epic cataclysm unfurl in the middle of a rush hour stricken New York City. The protagonist makes his way through a maze of abandoned vehicles as all around griffons are swooping down from the sky to snatch running civilians, and giant golems are smashing through skyscrapers. All of this wanton destruction sounds and looks amazing, until you realize it is all scripted and the player is in no danger. Furthermore, proceeding requires the player to stand in a specific spot that often looks like a dead end and wait for the scripted events to unlock the way forward. There are some good ideas and fun here, if you are willing to overlook the early 2000's budget feel of the game and pick it up at a steep discount, but there are definitely better ways to spend one’s time.

content:
r 2, 2014
												I bought this game already knowing it is a bad game, but it was under £1 and I figured 'how bad could it really be?'. Well, the answer to that is 'really, really bad'.So what makes it so bad? I'll exlain:Bland visuals with low quality texturesLimited weapon varietyLimited enemy varietyHorrible fps capBugsMore bugsGame-breaking bugsMassively bullet-spongey enemiesJanky controlsExtremely limited configuration optionsVolume issues in cut-scenesVery linearTerrible voice actingAbysmal animationsSo are there good things about the game? Well, it is, mercifully, quite short so you only need to waste a single afternoon/evening playing it. That's a good thing, I guess. Anything else? Nope. The game itself has almost no redeeming features whatsoever.Do not buy this game, no matter how cheap it is. It's not the waste of money that's the issue; it's the waste of time that could be better spent playing a game that isn't so awful.

content:
y 7, 2014
												What blows me away in the game industry is the time, effort, and dedication teams make to their craft. Oftentimes, it seems that teams who are so passionate about their projects for some reason or another just miss the mark. This is one of those occasions. The dev diaries, trailers, promotional materials all made this game seem extremely promising. Pandora's Box is opened and mythical creatures from Greek myths roam the lands in modern-day New York (I think?). Sounds cool, sounds fun, sounds "fresh" as the marketing and branding teams wants you to think.Do not, under any circumstances, purchase this game. This goes on the "why do I own this?" list of my collection. This shooter came out in the aftermath of a shooting rennaisance - Halo, Call of Duty(s), Battlefield(s), amongst many others - and yet couldn't take the queues from games that know how to make shooters and make a decent clone. A brief, and kind, summary:-poor controls-awful graphics-forgettable, unrelatable, and despicable protagonist-poor writing-absolutely no motivation for your actionsI would go more into depth with flowery prose, but I just want to distance myself from this game as soon as possible. I know many, many people spent years of their lives making this thing come together. I really wish they could have spent that time on a project that was enjoyable.Just... don't do it. You're better off using your money to wax your nether regions - it'll be more pleasurable.

content:
2015
												Ich kann nicht verstehen wie man bei dem Spiel Wirklich abraten kann... Zudem wenn ich einige der Negativen Rewiews lese glaube ich die Leute haben temporären Gedächtnisverlust...Zusammenfassung: Ja es ist kein Weltklasse-Shooter, aber bei einem Preis von 5 Euro ist das Spiel voll in Ordnung und hat viele gute Aspekte.Kurz was zur Story:Eine Story um Pandoras Box, Okay ein alter Hut Aber an sich ganz gut umgesetzt. Hier und da Logiklücken, aber für einen Shooter eine gute Story und gut in Szene gesetzt. Das Ende hat mich übrigens echt bedauern lassen dass es keinen 2. teil gibt, der wäre bestimmt nochmal besser als das hier. Das schlechte:Nun Zuerst muss man da wohl das Gunplay nennen. Es ist nicht kaputt, aber schwammig und im Zielmodus hat selbst die LMG kaum Rückstoß. Zudem stört das gerade im Schleichen extreme Headbobbing hier schon.. Dann noch die andauernden Zwangsbremsen... Hier mal eine Schalttafel überbrückt, hier ein Ventiel gedreht, Da was beiseite geschoben, Ehrlich gesagt, ich verstehe es nicht. Immer wieder muss man eine Tür durch eine übern Daumen ca 10sekündige Aktion öffnen. In den meisten Fällen passiert währenddessen gar nichts. (Ab und an kommt da was aber nur eine Hand voll im Spiel) Deas hält den Spielfluss auf stört aber im Endeffekt nur teils. Die KI der Menschlichen Gegner... Wir Schiebens mal auf: 'Der Fokus liegt auf den Monstern' Aber die Menschlichen Gegner sind dumm wie Brot und treffen teils schlechter als jeder Stormtrooper, Der Bösewicht hat wohl keine besonders hohen Einstellungsvoraussetzungen.Das 'an die Hand nehmen'... Es ist sooo bescheuert. Du brauchst nicht denken, alles was wichtig ist ist leuchtend hervorgehoben... Das Neutrale:Die Grafik ist mittelmaß, für seine Zeit und die UE3 nicht ganz zeitgemäß, aber es sieht Stellenweise echt gut aus, und an anderen Stellen wieder wie hinge... naja. Es ist ansehnlich, wenn man stellenweise wegguckt. Die KI der Monster, sie ist in Ordnung, aber stellenweise auch sehr vorhersehbar. Das Leveldesign, teils ist es ein Korridor of Duty, teils bietet es schöne offene Areale mit freiem vorgehen. Nichts besonders gutes, aber die Abwechslung empfinde ich positiv. Das gute: Die Monster. Es ist wirklich toll man hat hier 4 Permanente Gegnertypen, die man jeweils anders bekämpfen muss. Eine gute Abwechslung, die Spaß in den Kampf bringt und teilweise Schlachtflächen, die ein wenig nachdenken erfordern. Hätte ich gerne mehr von. Die Bosskämpfe sind extrem gut in Szene gesetzt ohne das Spielgeschehen zu unterbrechen, hierbei auch eine echt gute Umsetzung des Gegnerdesigns. Das Anima-System. Du kannst die Seelen der monster sdammeln und dich damit heilen(Und ein paar andere Dinge machen) Ein echt schönes System und eine gut umgesetzte Idee. Die Waffenauswahl ist in Ordnung und so gesehen ist jede Waffe hier gut einsetzbar. Trotz allem der Flammenwerfer ist zu stark. Bemerkungen am Rande:Der oft genannte Fahrstulbug ist bei mir nicht aufgetreten (Stand 7.5.15) Wird also weg sein. Der Multiplayer ist faktisch nicht mehr existent (Gamespy) LAN Ginge noch, aber ist halt LAN. Es gibt keinen Grund das Spiel auf Steam zu kaufen solange es nicht im Angebot ist. Wenn ihr wie ich Steam mögt ist Okay, aber es ist hierbei wirklich gleich wenn man sich eine DRM-Freie Version holt.

												This game if you was wondering is alright voice acting the A.I the story the enemys are all ok nothing stands out and can get very boring at times i recommanded playing on easy as it is not worth playing at harder difficulties as there is no benifit to playing on them.The game is worth getting as a time waster when it is discounted to under £1 and maybe if you are really bored £3 but i wouldn't as there is better games out there for the same price.The game has a great idea but the fantasy enemys are poorly done and not scary at all more a pain to deal with as once you kill one you can heal and the human enmeys are the only true threat other than the minotaur which is hard to kill as they soak up bullets and are weak at the back but other than that nothing is hard to deal with i would give this game 5 out of 10.

content:
2, 2014
												Good idea, bad execution. I was excited to play this game as I thought that it looked very interesting and to be a good game. I loved the idea of what this game was about, and it would've been a good game, but it was poorly made. A crappy fps with bad game mechanics and some poor graphics, but the graphics were as to expect from a game from 2008. The use of the healing and psy(?) powers did not work well for me, and I don't know if this was a problem only I was having, but for most of the game when I needed to, I could not heal. So I died, a lot. The walking speed is too slow in my opinion and for having a very short running period, so it's tedious to move around. (Jumping sucks too). But, the game still has it's fun moments. Just most of the moments are just tedious or not too exiting. It is an "okay" game, but I do not recommend to buy it unless it is on a very low sale. I got it for .74$ on a sale, and I think that it's a perfect price to pay for it. Only buy if its on sale for at least a dollar. I give the game 5/10.

												Legendary, it's a fun little game (although rather short), that doesn't need a good rig to run (looking at the specs), but I just can't recommend it:Pros:+ Enemies spawn a lot+ Graphics are decent+ Okay voice acting+ Cool powers+ Combat/Gunplay is alrightCons:- There's not much of storyline- Only a small amount of enemies (2-3)- Forgettable people- AI can be really dumb- Only 2 real uses for the power- Barriers galore- Really buggy- Can glitch up on you at times- Miniscule amount of weapons at your disposal- Little to no replay valueOverall, 4/10, whilst I enjoyed it, it just wasn't for me, too many negatives.

												I had this game back when I was a Xbox 360 user, and I remember it being pretty good and solid. Whoever did the PC port/version needs to be disembowled though. The game is visually unplayable. The textures are all gone. Everything is so, so, so bare. If you've ever used Zbrush, the characters are ALL that shade of grey, and so is the rest of the level. Particles are horrid. Flames are just red blocks. It isn't a problem on my end either. This game really is a visually dead port. Which is a shame, as I really liked it when I'd played the console version.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 30, 2013
												It's a shame really,  This game, judging by the screen shots, looked quite promising. However, it is let down frequently from the start by annoying and sometimes unnecessary development choices. If you are a fan of the invisible wall, you are in luck. The developer,  Spark Unlimited, almost certainly blew half their budget on them. They are implemented in a ' wait and see what we have to show you ' way. Fine, if you are building the up the story at a slow pace, and if obscured by scenery. However, the first ten minuets of the game are riddled with them, stopping you dead in your tracks in open space. They funnel you down certain paths to heighten the action and drama, but it's use is so sloppy that you will almost certainly be left more frustrated that captured by the environment.  The invisible walls will be placed in front of a small jump-able obstacle and open areas, or more often than not, dead in front of you so you physically stop to look at a set piece fall or some other mundane event. This is most noticeable in the beginning scene where you are told to flee from danger, only to be stopped ever 5 steps to watch the danger play out in front of you, while you stand their like a confused child. If you are expecting the sort of interactive storytelling more commonly associated with, Say, Half Life 2. You are out of luck. The opening scenes are a little like the beginning of Darksiders. Humans fleeing from winged monsters destroying a city around you. However, instead of capturing the excitement and joy that Darksiders offers, Legendarys offerings are much more hilarious. I laughed, audibly, when the ' Mexican Wave ' happened outside the museum. The hero of this game is, as in most FPS games, silent. But to make him seem more human and relatable, the developers applied Playstation 2 era facial animations to him. He is so convincing, his face slowly sliding into every expression known to man, that you will swear he has some form of medical condition. In fact, his appearance was so poorly handled I was sure the game was setting up the main villain.  To round this all off, once I acquired my first weapon I attempted to use it against the nearest enemy. But the axe just passed straight through it, over and over. The game was too busy showing me all the fun that I wouldn't be having.  The game feels unfinished, unpolished and linier. A cheap experience. What ever sale price this currently at, you would be better off keeping the money in your wallet and putting it towards a better game.

content:
er 29, 2013
												The game breaks from the CoD mass, using a JC2/FC2 like weapon system (managed by the directional pad on a controller, as a posed to a 2 weapon switch + inventory). Levels open up as you progress, atmosphere can swing from dark, highlighted coridors and sewers to bright courtyards in a church/cathedral, and the dusty, vehicle and debris filled streets of New York. The weapon list may be a short one, but each weapon has it's advantages over another, without filling your arsonal with random ♥♥♥♥. Beign a console to PC port it doesn't take much to run, but that doesn't mean the graphics don't look great (even for this year, I haven't even run it with GPU PhysX; my card is a 270X). The game is based on a health bar system, collecting the fuel to replenish it from dead mythicals.Personally the game felt a lot like FarCry 2, Crysis 2, and Bioshock to me (all in a good sense, I recognise that FC2 and C2 are hated amoung the series, but seriosly give all 4 of them a chance). When it comes to public reviews (Gamespot, IGN, etc.) the only honest reviews (I can find) come from PlayStation Magazine (less so, a little harsh but Sony does force their exclusives onto people of the wrong demographic all the god-damn time), GameInformer (also a little harsh, it's the Unreal Engine (no offense), it can't do  really increadable things  (Antichamber was a greate game, but there are graphic ♥♥♥♥ who critisize it)), Gameplanet and Xbox Magazine, these 4 being less intimidated by Gears of War 2 (Impossible from PDM), FarCry 2, Call of Duty WAW and other during it's release.While I haven't tried the multiplayer mode myself (I have also heard that there aren't many players), the game doesn't really on PvP TDM, but more a single, objective based gametype where you collect the essence from the mythicals, first to fill their collector wins.I sugest having an Xbox 360 controller for this, being a game that was developed on consoles (I would recomend a controller anyway, it isn't PvP so you won't get beaten by an elite player with a laser/high accuracy/performance mouse). PS. IGN is still a  really  ♥♥♥♥♥♥ company/site/place.

												Jan 8, 2013: This game has a promising premise, but it is plagued with flaws. Even on my good computer, I get frame-rate drops to near-crashes.. What a shame really.Aside from that, it makes me sort've remember playing Half-Life 2 in some ways. Not much else to say about it since the issue with the drops has stopped me from playing, for the most part.UPDATE, Sep 19, 2014: So, after pretty much ignoring this title in my list and letting it rot, I'm finally giving it a whirl again and would believe it took a massive, ridiculous upgrade past the requirements to get this to work better? 24 gigs of ram and a GeForce GT 740 -- there's still some clipping here and there, but overall the framerate drops are less dramatic, making this game playable. I've also tested disabling HID compliant devices in the device panel, which seemed to help. For anyone looking to get this sucker working, I would recommend the HID compliant items be disabled first. That may have been the issue from the getgo.

												I had a great time with this game, i walked into it expecting problems due to the reviews but i never once encountered a noticable glitch or failure, there is one thing that i hated the most about this game, the jumping you jump like an inch, and it feels like there shouldn't even be jumping, but if you want to go 30 mph just get to a ledge and sprint jump off, you'll go flying. This game has alot of cool moments, but at other times it feels a tad bit boring. Especially at the end, there isn't any feeling of urgency during the final level. I only died once, and it was because one of the monsters in this game, the minotaur, is a pain in the ♥♥♥. He will constantly follow you, running at your pace unless your sprinting, he flawless tails you even when charging, he runs through the walls in the arenas, that they put you in to fight him, flawlessly, it's like he can walk through the damn things. The game tells you to shoot him in the back, and that is super difficult because he rarely charges and when he does, it's hard to dodge. Every other enemy though is easy to fight. This game will turn into a puzzle game easily, there will be times where you have no idea what to do, and the solution is so obvious you don't notice it. The weapon switch is super slow. When you try to heal yourself with the "aminus" juice you have, it takes a little longer than it should, and is hard to control. God help you if you're trying to pick up a weapon while running if you're being chased, it's a huge thing that would've helped me during a lot of battles. On the good side the cutscenes, soundtrack, atmosphere is amazing, the AI is ok, i've seen them do some stupid ♥♥♥♥ though. Overall for five dollars i think this is a steal, if you like games with good graphics that run well even on the highest settings with bad pc parts, this is your game, my ram runs at like 500 mhz, and i ran it on highest settings.

content:
4, 2014
												I know the second you saw this you were confused. Legendary a good game?!?!? But I am being serious here. I loved this game. Everyone says either "It is pretty moderate for a shooter" or "Bad game"  which I don't understand at all. I had more fun with this shooter than COD! In COD you fight a bunch of similair stupid ♥♥♥ enemies who have no special abilities at all. Or you play an average zombie survival mode. Or you play online agains't a bunch of screaming kids and swearing adults with absolutely no innovation at all even in the sequels it is almost exactly the same. What happens in Legendary? Griffins swoop down picking up enemies in their mouths and eating them. Werewolfs lunge at you and throw objects at you and when they are killed you have to chop of their heads or they recuperate. Fire drakes shoot fire out of their mouths at you but can be taken care of by activating a sprinkler or shooting a fire extinguisher. And while you are doing this a MASSIVE golem above is smashing through buildings and stepping on fleeing people. Also a giant tentacled beast is grabbing allies and pulling them to a watery grave. And guess what. Those tentacles can also grab you and the golem can also step on you. All these mythical creatures from different cultures are trying to kill you while you are trying to destroy a golem by activating 3 EMPs to seperate the energy of the golem from the body. Explosive spiders from Japan, Fire Drakes from old tales and a Kraken from common folklore. My favourite creature is the Nari. A creepy bat like creature with a childs face who can become a ghost and              a physical creature. They often possess objects and throw them at you and generally make life a pain. They steal objects needed for objectives and force you to chase them down often leading you to traps. One time a Nari stole a valve I needed to proceed and dropped it in a suspicious looking chamber. When I entered the doors closed and a fan possessed by the Nari  started sucking me towards it. Only by shooting the supports could I barely escape and when I did I was attacked by a tentacle and almost pulled towards my doom. And that is only level 2. The only bad thing I would say about this game is the graphics however because of the graphics it works on less powerful computers like mine. Some of the most popular games also have bad graphics like HL2 and Killing Floor but noone complains about that. All in all I would give it an 8/10. Definitely worth playing and fun.

content:
2, 2015
												This game is worth $5... no more... no less.5 hours of game play.50 minutes of headaches.5 minutes of bad cut scenes5 mins of editing INI files.50 secounds of fun with the flamethrower.This isn't a bad game. It's not a good game. It's a game. Interesting plot/story in so far as the mythology is concerned. TERRIBLE voice acting. Truly the actors either didn't care or were directed badly. Either way it's not good.The save check point is annoying but not terrible since it saves your weapons and reloads all your ammo.The power yes... one. Could have been interested or at least had upgrades but no...All in all it's a fun distraction and if you're looking for an average FPS where you are the Hero and saviour of mankind then yes this game is for you.One thing though... there is a nasty clipping bug for the final level where you fall through the last elevator... horrifying that this wasn't addressed by the developer.No patch just some advice involving INI files.Here is the solution that worked for me. Best of luck fellow gamer.Here is a fix that works for most people.Open the PandoraEngine.ini (on vista it is on C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\My Games\Legendary\PandoraGame\Config-Folder) and search for"MaxSmoothedFrameRate=300" and change the value to 60. So the game runs at maximum 60 fps. Play through to next check point save then edit it back to 300 and continue game.If a setting of 60 does not work try 30.Game will not run so good but it's only a short run to the next checkpoint where you can then reset back to 300 and trust me you will want to.GG.

content:
ry 17, 2016
												I think this game rightfully gets in the mixed ratings category, but please don't skip this game simply because not everyone said it was good.It is a very standard FPS, but the mythological enemies really do sell it for me. How many FPS games do you get to lob a molatov cocktail at a werewolf and fire rockets at griffons? And the other legendary monsters are all very unique and fun to fight.The story is kinda basic too and the characters are a bit bland (you play as a silent protagonist for crying out loud) but I didn't pay the small price tag to get great literary characters (but I admit it would be awesome if I had). Actually it's probably better that the protagonist is silent, it keeps it from making him "edgy" like all the current heroes need to be.And it is a small price tag, but it is a short game: 7 hours for me on hard.I'd just say that I really enjoyed it and would probably play it again just because of the enemies. They really are fun to fight and even just to get scared of when you realize a werewolf is right behind you. The set pieces are fun too from the odd little boss fights to the tracking down a device to open the next door to just stopping and taking in the craziness of what's going on where you are.One more thing: I didn't really have the best computer to render graphics for this game. It was like playing an alpha build for it. And even when the werewolves, floor, and walls didn't have textures on them I still was having a blast. I know some people would have a problem with that if their computer isn't good enough though.It's not Halo, it's not Half-life (although I see some similarities), but it doesn't have to be. It's unique. High recommendations.

content:
ry 15, 2016
												Legendary is a pretty good first-person shooter full of intense action. I wasn't really expecting much, but it turned out to be a good buy. The story is nothing special, the game's rather linear and you can't backtrack, but that doesn't really bother me. The action is great and there's lots of it. Some of the enemies are really tough, but man do you feel like Rambo mowing down everyone with a machine gun.One thing that bothers me is that switching weapons doesn't seem to have any logic (I guess it changes depending on which one you picked up last), and I always choose the wrong weapon first, which is annoying in the middle of action. And even though the game is linear, there are still some "where do I go, what do I do" moments, and the rapidly spawning enemies don't help. But most of the time the game works well and is really fun. If you like Half-Life style action, you could check this out.+ Full of intense action+ Good weapons+ Interesting enemies+ Solid graphics and music (though nothing special)+ Challenging but fun~ Linear, can't backtrack (doesn't really bother me)- Weapon switching is confusing- The mouse is not very precise when aiming with sights or scope4/5

content:
9, 2015
												So, as someone who REALLY wanted this game and was super hyped for it back when it was first announced but chose not to get it after the horrible reviews, here's my review after finally picking this game up.Overall, I'd say it's a pretty good little game.  I definitely wouldn't have paid full price for it at launch now that I've seen it myself, but for the current price on Steam?  Definitely worth it.Pros:-Interesting enemies.  Werewolves and griffons in New York?  As cool now as it was back when this game came out.-Destructible terrain.  I've had enemies blow up bits of walls that I had no idea they could blow up so they could shoot me in the face.  There's a surprising amount of stuff that can be blasted apart to get at the enemy, and I really think this game could have done a little better if they had pushed this point a little harder.Cons:-Endless enemies.  Some areas the enemies just keep spawning and attacking you until you perform a certain action, other areas you simply can't advance until you've killed enough enemies.  The fights where you have to kill a number of enemies tend to drag on, so it gets hard to tell which type of fight you're involved in.-Poor AI.  This is one of the killing points for this game after having the team hype up how advanced it would be.  I've seen enemies run circles around other enemies because the other guy was sitting where they wanted to sit.  And don't get me started on the number of times guys with shotguns thought they could peg me from the other side of a battlefield.-Buggy.  Quite buggy.  Loading from a checkpoint seems to respawn ALL enemies, even ones that you killed before reaching the checkpoint, and there's a fatal bug right before the final battle that you'll need to edit the game files to get around.-Story/writing.  Okay, I normally avoid bringing writing up, but when a guy comments about how he shouldn't be poking the mysterious puss sack only to start poking it again I'm going to complain.The game costs like $3 on Steam.  It's worth the price for a few hours of silly monster-mashing fun.  I admit I haven't beaten the game (I'm of the opinion that the final battle is just extremely poorly designed) but I absolutely have no regrets buying it.  The game probably would have done better in it's day if it had a lower price and wasn't hyped as much as it was, but as it's got neither the hype nor the price these days there's no reason not to check it out.

Lucky Star is what Seinfeld might have been had it been animated, featured high school girls instead of adults, and slanted specifically at hard-core otaku. content:
er 30, 2013
												It's a shame really,  This game, judging by the screen shots, looked quite promising. However, it is let down frequently from the start by annoying and sometimes unnecessary development choices. If you are a fan of the invisible wall, you are in luck. The developer,  Spark Unlimited, almost certainly blew half their budget on them. They are implemented in a ' wait and see what we have to show you ' way. Fine, if you are building the up the story at a slow pace, and if obscured by scenery. However, the first ten minuets of the game are riddled with them, stopping you dead in your tracks in open space. They funnel you down certain paths to heighten the action and drama, but it's use is so sloppy that you will almost certainly be left more frustrated that captured by the environment.  The invisible walls will be placed in front of a small jump-able obstacle and open areas, or more often than not, dead in front of you so you physically stop to look at a set piece fall or some other mundane event. This is most noticeable in the beginning scene where you are told to flee from danger, only to be stopped ever 5 steps to watch the danger play out in front of you, while you stand their like a confused child. If you are expecting the sort of interactive storytelling more commonly associated with, Say, Half Life 2. You are out of luck. The opening scenes are a little like the beginning of Darksiders. Humans fleeing from winged monsters destroying a city around you. However, instead of capturing the excitement and joy that Darksiders offers, Legendarys offerings are much more hilarious. I laughed, audibly, when the ' Mexican Wave ' happened outside the museum. The hero of this game is, as in most FPS games, silent. But to make him seem more human and relatable, the developers applied Playstation 2 era facial animations to him. He is so convincing, his face slowly sliding into every expression known to man, that you will swear he has some form of medical condition. In fact, his appearance was so poorly handled I was sure the game was setting up the main villain.  To round this all off, once I acquired my first weapon I attempted to use it against the nearest enemy. But the axe just passed straight through it, over and over. The game was too busy showing me all the fun that I wouldn't be having.  The game feels unfinished, unpolished and linier. A cheap experience. What ever sale price this currently at, you would be better off keeping the money in your wallet and putting it towards a better game.

2, 2015
												This game is worth $5... no more... no less.5 hours of game play.50 minutes of headaches.5 minutes of bad cut scenes5 mins of editing INI files.50 secounds of fun with the flamethrower.This isn't a bad game. It's not a good game. It's a game. Interesting plot/story in so far as the mythology is concerned. TERRIBLE voice acting. Truly the actors either didn't care or were directed badly. Either way it's not good.The save check point is annoying but not terrible since it saves your weapons and reloads all your ammo.The power yes... one. Could have been interested or at least had upgrades but no...All in all it's a fun distraction and if you're looking for an average FPS where you are the Hero and saviour of mankind then yes this game is for you.One thing though... there is a nasty clipping bug for the final level where you fall through the last elevator... horrifying that this wasn't addressed by the developer.No patch just some advice involving INI files.Here is the solution that worked for me. Best of luck fellow gamer.Here is a fix that works for most people.Open the PandoraEngine.ini (on vista it is on C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\My Games\Legendary\PandoraGame\Config-Folder) and search for"MaxSmoothedFrameRate=300" and change the value to 60. So the game runs at maximum 60 fps. Play through to next check point save then edit it back to 300 and continue game.If a setting of 60 does not work try 30.Game will not run so good but it's only a short run to the next checkpoint where you can then reset back to 300 and trust me you will want to.GG.
